docs.abstract: The transition to new fifth-generation networks, known as 5G, will affect how you use smartphones and many other devices. Let’s talk about the essentials.
docs.snippet: The transition to new fifth-generation networks, known as 5G, will affect how you use smartphones and many other devices. Let’s talk about the essentials.
docs.lead_paragraph: A big technology shift is underway, bringing a once-in-a-decade upgrade to the wireless systems that deliver data to mobile phones.

headline.main: What Is 5G? Here’s What You Need to Know About the New Cellular Network
headline.print_headline: What 5G Will Mean When It Arrives This Year

docs.abstract: Europe’s central bank took control of troubled Banca Carige, an unprecedented step to manage risk as Italy’s political and economic woes continue.
docs.snippet: Europe’s central bank took control of troubled Banca Carige, an unprecedented step to manage risk as Italy’s political and economic woes continue.
docs.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank took control of a troubled Italian bank Wednesday, an unprecedented step that spotlighted the risks to the eurozone’s financial system from political chaos in Rome and a sputtering economy.

headline.main: E.C.B. Takes Reins of Italian Bank to Prevent Wider Crisis
headline.print_headline: European Bank Takes Helm Of Troubled Italian Lender

docs.abstract: A glut of unwanted apartments gets part of the blame for a slowdown in the world’s second-largest economy. In some places, homeowners are taking to the streets.
docs.snippet: A glut of unwanted apartments gets part of the blame for a slowdown in the world’s second-largest economy. In some places, homeowners are taking to the streets.
docs.lead_paragraph: JURONG, China — For Hu Peiliang, Jurong was a city of cranes, concrete and opportunity. He was so sure it was on the cusp of a boom that last year he moved his family there.

headline.main: Empty Homes and Protests: China’s Property Market Strains the World

byline.original: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

docs.abstract: The Times Square Alliance joined with the Committee to Protect Journalists to send millions of viewers a message on the importance of journalism.
docs.snippet: The Times Square Alliance joined with the Committee to Protect Journalists to send millions of viewers a message on the importance of journalism.

headline.main: As New Year’s Eve Ball Drops, the Free Press Gets a Moment in the Spotlight
headline.print_headline: A Rockin’ New Year’s Eve With Sting, Ninja and a Free Press

docs.abstract: Starting a new job, an employee is already preparing to quit because of a supervisor who repeatedly levels unfair critiques and then apologizes.
docs.snippet: Starting a new job, an employee is already preparing to quit because of a supervisor who repeatedly levels unfair critiques and then apologizes.
docs.lead_paragraph: Starting somewhere new after working at one company for 18 years inevitably entails some adjustments and bumpiness. So before you make a rash decision to bail on this new gig, make at least some effort to figure out whether you and your new boss can adjust to each other.

headline.main: What to Do About an Overly Critical Boss
headline.print_headline: Braving a Storm of Irritating Indignities

docs.abstract: Congress may still approve a raise, perhaps as part of legislation to reopen the government. But union leaders condemned the order as unnecessary provocation.
docs.snippet: Congress may still approve a raise, perhaps as part of legislation to reopen the government. But union leaders condemned the order as unnecessary provocation.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Trump issued an executive order on Friday freezing pay for federal civilian workers in 2019, even as about 800,000 of them were either furloughed or working without pay because of a partial government shutdown.

headline.main: Trump Issues Order Freezing Federal Workers’ Pay in 2019
headline.print_headline: Trump Orders Pay Freeze For Federal Civilian Staff

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

docs.abstract: When news of natural disasters or man-made ones break in the U.S., Julie Bloom taps a variety of tools to communicate with reporters, edit stories and get them published.
docs.snippet: When news of natural disasters or man-made ones break in the U.S., Julie Bloom taps a variety of tools to communicate with reporters, edit stories and get them published.
docs.lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Julie Bloom, a deputy editor for national coverage for The Times, discussed the tech she’s using.

headline.main: Hurricanes. Shootings. Fires. Time for an Editor’s Emergency Kit.
headline.print_headline: When Disaster Strikes, Open the Editor’s Tool Kit

docs.abstract: Many other countries are adopting or considering stricter moderation of online speech. But they don’t have to work around the First Amendment.
docs.snippet: Many other countries are adopting or considering stricter moderation of online speech. But they don’t have to work around the First Amendment.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook called for regulating harmful internet content in an opinion column last month, Republicans in Washington expressed outrage that he was calling on the government to regulate speech.

headline.main: It’s U.S. vs. World as Big Tech Faces Specter of Limiting Speech Online
headline.print_headline: Can Tech Companies Silence Hate Speech?

docs.abstract: The key question is whether the legislation she has proposed is the best means to police corporate leaders.
docs.snippet: The key question is whether the legislation she has proposed is the best means to police corporate leaders.
docs.lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline.main: Elizabeth Warren Wants to Make It Easier to Prosecute Executives

docs.abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chairman, also said that if asked to resign by President Trump, he would refuse.
docs.snippet: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chairman, also said that if asked to resign by President Trump, he would refuse.
docs.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chairman, said Friday that low inflation would allow the Fed to be “patient” in deciding whether to continue raising interest rates, a message welcomed by jittery investors.

headline.main: Powell Says a ‘Patient’ Fed Is Watching for Signs of Economic Weakness
headline.print_headline: Promise From Powell, Mixed With Defiance: ‘We Will Be Patient’

byline.original: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Jim Tankersley
